messageBody:
Shaun--

I've been dealing with the similar roblem. An easy way is to write a
class that extends TestSuite that takes a file as a constructor (say,
XmlSuiteReader). Then write another class that extends TestCase that
takes a string as a constructor (say, XmlTestReader).

XmlSuiteReader should parse the XML file into test cases (line-by-line,
or between tags, etc) and, for each one, create add a new XmlTestReader
test case. XmlTestReader parses the XML string passed to it by
XmlSuiteReader and sets its instance variables sothat it can run the
test and report an appropriate error. XmlTestReader's run() method then
runs the appropriate test.

Sorry if this description is a little vague, but it should work well for
your purposes.

--Sameer

> Hi I'm new to the group but already a massive fan of Junit.
>
> Q. I'd like to know if there is a way of dynamically constructing my test
> methods in my TestCase class. I'm writing a system test harness that reads
> in the test commands from an xml script and ideally would like to execute
> the tests encoded in each of the xml records as a separate TestCase method.
> As it stands I can only see the possibility of running all of the test
> records in one TestCase method and only therefore get one status result.
>
> Sorry if this is an FAQ BTW where are the faqs ?
>
> Regards,
>
> Shaun O'Hagan
> Nokia UK.
